Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week for Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

Venus is an evening star.

Saturn is visible nearly all night except towards the end of the month, when it sets at 1.30 am.
The chief constellations in the South at 9p.m. are Perasus (Chief star Merkab) bear the Zenith, Aquarius about 600 and Capricornus about 400, above the horizon.

div.head: The Sultan's Successor
div.p: The Constantinople correspondent of the "Tribune" in a recent letter to our contemporary concerning the much discussed question of the succession to the throne of Turkey writes as follows:—For some weeks there have mysterious rumours of the possibility of an attempt to change the succession to the Turkish throre. The most persistent is that it is the desire of Abdul Hamid to appoint his third son, Prince Burhan-ed-din, as his successor, and for this purpose to obtain the consent of the Sheik-ul Islam and of the Ambassadors of the Great Powers. It is even added that Abdul Hamid is thinking of abdicating in favour of this prince. The rumoured step would be an exceedingly grave one. It is probable that any attempt to make such a change without the consent of the ulema class, of whom the Sheik. al-Islam is the head, would fail, and might simply plange the country into revolution. It is further rumoured that the Sheik-ul-Islam has seen sounded, and that he has declared that such a change could never be sanctioned. This, however, I do not believe. Rumour further says that the German Emperor has | been asked for his counsel, and that the sudden return here, & week ago, of the German Ambassador is in connection with this question. While fully admitting that we are dealing only with rumours, these are so persistent and definite as to suggest that they have a basis of truth, and the questions raised by them become interesting and important.

The Moslem law of succession to a royal throne is based upon long usage, and enacts that the heir is the oldest male in the Royal for Imperial family. A simple illustration is furnished by the recent history of Egypt. When Mehmet Ali became, by Imperial firman and the recognition of Europe, Khedive of Egypt, the Sultan issued a firman in 1846 by which the succession was to be regulated] in the Moslem fashion--that is, the heir was always to be the eldest male descended from Mehmet Ali. The rule was strictly followed till the time of Ismail. On the death of Ismail the legal heir to the Khedival throne should have been Prince Halim, the youngest son of Mehmet Ali. But Ismail, in 1866, by means of very heavy payments, had induced Abdul Aziz, the Sultan of Turkey (who was deposed, and 'suicided" in 1876), to grant a new firman,, by which the succession was changed from the Moslem to the general European system of succession. When the representatives of England and France decided in 1879 to get rid of Ismail, they secretly, but unmistakably, gave him the opportunity to leave Egypt quietly, in which case the firman which he had obtained would be recognized, and his son allowed to reign in his stead. If he refused, Halim, the "de jure'' heir by Moslem law, would be placed on the throne. He agreed to go quietly. It was generally believed in this city that Abdul Aziz, in granting the firman changing the Egyptian succession, had the intention to change the succession to the Turkish throne. In such case Prince Yussuf Izzedin would have been the heir apparent, Tho revolution of 1876 put an end to any such design, and Murad, and then the present occupant, were girded with the Sword of Osman in conformity with the well-established rule. At the time, however, when the project of changing the Ottoman rule of succession was in the air, it was well

understood that the ulema clans were strongly opposed to it. They represent the conservative element of Islam ; and unless some very special circumstances should be brought forward, they would oppose a stout resistance to any change of the kind. The present heir to the throne is Reshad Effendi, the Sultan's brother. Both he and two elder brothers rank, on the ground of age, before the third son of the present Sultan. The supposed favourite of his Majesty for the succession is his third son, who is known to the Ambassadors as a bright and intelligent young man of about twenty years old. The question is mainly, though not exclusively, of course, one for the subjects of his Majesty, and especially for his Monlem | subjects. If the change is attempted, it will probably give rise to considerable trouble. -

The suggestion that Abdul Hamid would be willing to abdicate does not strike me as probable. Those who are in favour of his doing so speak disparagingly of Reshad Effendi; but there will be always a party strongly in his favour as representing the reign of Moslema law. There are precedents for passing over the heir, but the change has always been regarded as revolutionary.

Though, of course, the personality of the Sultan is for foreign States a matter of great importance, the representatives of such States will probably best consult the interests of their Governments, and certainly of Turkey, by having nothing to do with any proposal to change the succession. The fact that they or any of them favoured one candidate more than another would do much to make him unpopular with the Moslem population. The matter is primarily one for the Moslem people of Turkey, and for a foreign Govern. ment to pronounce an opinion one way or another would have the appearance of mixing in a Palace intrigue. If it be said that Turkey is more or less under European tutelage, and that the unanimous consent of Europe to s change of Moslem law would give it a sanction which would secure its general acceptance, my reply would be that unanimity on this subject is impossible, and to attempt to obtain it would occasion endless intrigue. It may be admitted that if the general consent of Europe could be obtained it might establish an important precedent. But if such consent has been applied for, and il, as is rumoured, negotiations are going on, it is because opposition is anticipated either by Turkey or by some foreign State. Even an attempt by the Concert of Europe would be denounced by the Moslem population as an interference by the giaours with their religious rights, | There is much to be said for and much against the alleged project. The generally expressed opinion is that certain Palace favourites, for their own purposes, are in its favour, and this would not recommend it to the Turkish population, and still less to Europeans. Indeed, in whatever way the expe. diency of a change in the law of succession may be regarded, its practical application will be dangerous. It will almost certainly lead to disturbances, and it ought to be a question for Turkish statesmen whether it is desirable to add to the many difficulties with which they have to deal a possible war of succession. For foreign States the question is at once tempting and dangerous. In the solution of the many questions in the Near East with which our country is concerned, it is difficult to see what advantage could be gained by entering upon it. Sir Edward Grey will probably conclude that his wisest course is to reserve speech or action, and take up the poste tion that Great Britain will stand aloof, and neither approve nor disapprove any action of the kind which the Palace advisers may choose to take.

div.head:
THE IMMODERATE PRESS
NOT ADMITTED TO SUDAN.
div.p: "Al Minbar" states in its issue of yesterday that it has received an official communication announcing that the journal will not be admitted into the Sadun. We can only express approval at the action of the Sudan Government in view of the immoderation with which to "Al Minbar" discusses political question relating to the occupying Power. The organa of the nationalist party have assumed the foolish course of indulging in mere tirade against the advisers of the Khedive, and by such bring upon themselves the possibility of a perfectly justifiable suppression. We are rather inclined to hope that the prohibition of such intemperate journals in the Sudan is an augury of the application of a censorship over the Press of Egypt. It is exceedingly regrettable that there should be cause to seriously consider such an innovation, but a certain section, which is not constituted by our vernacular contemporaries alone, bas become so seditious that we should feel ourselves obliged to support the Government in any means which they might deem necessary to check the violent and harmful declamations of unreasoning journaliste. Let such take a lesson from the suppression of "Al Minbar" in the Sudan, and learn that their turbulence may preclude them from the liberty which moderation would ansare and from the consideration of serious men.

div.head: The Plague
div.p: Two new plague patients were admitted to hospital at Suez yesterday and one patient was discharged.

div.p: The new oph.halmio hospital at Assiout war formally opened yesterday in the presence of pr
the moudir of the province.

div.head: Malouan Observatory.
div.p: The observatory will be open to the public on the 11th inst, on which occasion the Survey Department will be "at home."

div.head: Military Exemption.
div.p: The military exemption tax between January and August 31, 1906, realized L.E.164,900 as against L.E. 116,920 for the same period last year.

div.head: St Andrew's Church, Alexandria.
div.p: The sacrament of the Lord's Supper will be w celebrated on Sunday morning at the close of
the morning service. Friends and visitors are cordially invited.

div.head: The Pilgrimage.
div.p: Two days ago, 150 Turkish pilgrims arrived at [illegible] where they passed a couple of days and they have now proceeded to Suez to embark for the Hedjaz.

div.head: Law School Graduates.
div.p: By ranetiori of the Ministry of Justice, a number of graduates of the Khedivial Law School have been appointed "substituto du parquet" at the native courts.

div.head: European Police for Egypt.
div.p: Provision has been made in the budget of the Ministry of the Interior for 1907 for the European police who are to be attached to the forces at Cairo and Alexandria.

div.head: Cairo Circulating Library.
div.p: On and after Monday, 8th October, the Cairo Circulating Library will be open at the usual winter hours, viz. from 10.20 a.m. to midday and from 4.30 to 6 p.m. of each day except Sunday.

div.head: Comptoir National d'Escompte
div.p: The Cairo branch of the Comptoir National d'Escompte, Paris, to be inaugurated on the 15th inst., will be temporarily housed in the Maison Manusardi. Emad el Dio Avenne, near the Hotel d'Angleterre.

div.head: National University.
div.p: The subscription towards the foundation of a National University has reached LE. 2,100.1. It is feared in some quarters that this scheme of a National University will share the same fate as that drawn up by several Khedivial princes and Egyptian notables at the time of the Mohamed Ali centenary.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: On October 3, 6 vessels, 2 northward and 4; southward bound, transited the Canal and paid Fr. 177,712 50 for transit and passenger toll. Of these vessels, 3 were British, 2 German and Austrian. The total receipts since October 1 are Fr. 639,119.92, paid by 25 vessels, of which 9 were northward and 16 southward bound.

div.head: Slave Trade.
div.p: Mohamed Naeser, the notorious slave dealer, has at last been caught, after having eluded the vigilance of be authorities for eight years. Mohamel, who is the head of the El Parayat | tribe, is famous for the pitobed battle he fought with the police on September 28, 1905, where | ten of his band were arrested and condemned to 15 years' hard labor. Lately the band were surprized with 12 slaves, whom the patrol, however, were unable to liberate, owing to the resistance shown by the Bedonin.

div.head: New Employment Registry.
div.p: The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

Signor Nerazzini, Italian Consul General at Shanghai, has been appointed Minister at Tangier, and Cav. Malmusi transferred to Cairo. Marquis Salvago Raggi has been transferred to Zanzibar. Signor L. Meroatelli has been appointed Consul General at Calcutta. SIgnor Medana, Consul General at Tripoli, has been transferred to Teheran. Signor A. Monaco, Consul General at Seoul, has been transferred to Shanghai. (Reuter)
M. Malmasi, Minister at Morocco, has been appointed Minister at Cairo, vice the Marquis Salvago-Raggi, who is appointed Consul General at Zanzibar and Governor of Benadir. (H.)

The successor to the Marquis Salvago-Raggi at Cairo, Signor Giulio Malmusi, was born at Parma on the 15th April, 1841, and entered the Foreign Office at Rome on the 14th January, 1861. In the following year he was Appointed a Vice-Consul of the third class an 11 proceeded to Barcelona. He was advanced to the second class in 1865. He has been Vice-Consul at Gibraltar, Bona, and Trebizond. In 1872 he became a Vice-Consul of the first class and a Chevalier of the Crown of Italy two years afterwards. He went to Cairo as Consul in 1874 and to Alexandria in 1877, whence he was transferred to Phillipopolis in 1879. He became Agent and Consul General at Tonia in 1884 and subsequently held the Consul. Generalship at Liverpool and Trieste and was appointed Minister Plenipotentiary at Tangiers in 1595. In 1999 he was nominated Consul-General of the First Class.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: This morning, the Khedive came from Montazah to Ras El Tin Palace, and at noon proceded to the Ghamrawi mosque in the Customs quarter, where his Highness attended prayer.

div.head: SIR VINCENT CORBETT.
div.p: Quidnuncs in Cairo are busy finding a post in the diplomatic service for Sir Vinoent Corbett, owing to the romours afloat as to the Financial Adviser leaving the service of the Egyptian Government in order to take a position under the Foreign Office. Last week they had discovered a high position for him in the Legation at Brussels; the week before it was Vienna !

div.head:
THE LABBAN AFFAIR.
POLICEMEN NOT GUILTY.
div.p: The Gouvernorat has received an official communication from the Parquet notifying! that Onbashi Mohamed Taha and shawish Ibrahim Abd-el-Aal, who were charged with
having caused the death of Osman Ahmed - have been acquitted as not guilty and ordered to resume their duties.
The following in a summary of the contents of the document sent by the Parquet Gépét Cairo, to the Chef da Parquet of Alexandru in regard to the affair:

Having carefully examined the official papers 1 of inquiry held by the Alexandrian Parquet; and the decision of the Council of Discipline held at the Alexandria Government, regarding the death of Osman Ahmed, we find that the policemen Mohamed Taha and Ibrahim Abdel Aal are quite blameless on the ground that medical reports show that the death of the deceased was due to internal disease. The trial of the accused held by the Council of Discipline contains no evidence to incriminate the onbashi and shawish, and, moreover, the two witnesses being of the deceased's relatives, who prepared the charge against the policemen, their evidence can not be considered and furthermore the supposition that the policemen treated the man with some cruelty in the course of their duties affords, insufficient ground to incriminate them.

div.head: THE CENSUS OF EGYPT.
div.p: The preparations for taking the census of Egypt have already begun. Mr. Lewis, whose services have been engaged for taking the census by the Egyptian Government on account of his great experience in similar work in India, arrived at Alexandria yesterday, and paid a visit to the Alexandria Municipality in order to obtain some preliminary information on the subject of his new duties.

div.head:
THE SINAITIC BOUNDARY.
MR. KEELING IN DANGER.
div.p: Owen Rey and Fakhry Pasha are on their way to Akaba from Rafah, superintending en

route the erection of boundary pillars on each side of the frontier, at intervals of one mile. We understand that on their arrival at Akaba they will return by way of fort Nakhl on the way to Suez, from whence they will proceed direct to Cairo. We are assured that the relations between the Anglo Egyptian and Ottoman commissioners were extremely friendly. On the other hand, Mr. Keeling, of the Barvey Department, who was attached to the Commission, had a narrow escape between Akaba and Kuseima, at the hands of a raiding party of Bedouins, who had crossed the frontier in to attack one of the Bedouin tribes under Egyptian protection. As Mr. Kooling's guide belonged to the latter tribe his position might have proved very dangerous, but the Bedouins fortunately did not press their enquiries too close by Mr. Keeling's guide succeeded in persuading the leaders of the raiding party that he had no connection whatever with their enemies.

div.head:
MUSTAPHA PASHA KAMEL
THB PROPOSED BANQUET.
div.p: Our Nationalist confrères are making the best of their time before Moustapha Pasha Kamel returns. "Al Moayad" criticises the Pasha's letter to Farid Bey as insincere.

Our confrère remarks : "He still considera bia enemies and his critica as opponents of true patriotism, enemies of all honest devotion to their country. He is modest-- he only hopes that the great gift of a University will be offered to Egypt in his name. We suppose he intends to lay the foundation stone himself."

"Al Watan", the well-known Coptic organ, remarks a propos of the Pasha's lotter to Farid Bey : --"Mastapha Pasha Kamel is far too modest in his assertion that he has done nothing worth repeating. He forgets or pretends to forget that he has sown the seeds of discord between Moslem and Copt, between Egyptian and Syrian ; that he bas declared England to be the deadly foe of Islam; that he taught Moslem to hate Christian, has brought England's anger upon us, has created that state of excitement among us which was described as fanaticism in the English Parliament and that he is the cause of all measuras taken or to be taken by England to close her grip on the land and responsible for the very unflattering opinion the English have formed of us."
"Al Mokattım” learns from a correspondent the details of the moon at the banquet which I will be given to Moustapha Pasha at the Grand Continental hotel.

div.head:
BLUNT'S ANTI-NATIONALSIM
HIS BIASSED CRITICISMS.
div.p: A correspondent writes as follows

You published the day before yesterday a letter to the "Times" from the pen of Mr. Blant, who therein expresses has "onlooked for pleasure" at finding himself "once more attacked, after a silence of some twenty years” by his old adversary, Mr. Moberly Bell. One can fully understand Mr. Blant's delight at the advertisement which he has received from a journal than which none other in the world stands higher, and were it not impossible to disregard the aspersions by which he tries to vilify his mother-dation, the publicity which he has received would be regrettable. Righteous indignation rankles in th: best of every true Britisher at the calomnies which are cast upon his nation by distorted fasts emanating from one of the Empire's song. Were Mr. Blunt content to criticise his country in an equitable spirit, to endeavour to obtain true and unbiased accounts of the happenings in Egypt, and to moderate his acrimony, one might read lo with interest and seriously consider his I writing. But his obvious hatred for his country makes one feel that it is impossible to wage with him the war of pens with the feeling that he is an adversary worthy of the steel.

Mr. Blunt's asseveration that the "Times" exaggerates his anti English attitude cannot be accepted, as, in the opinion of every right minded person, a man who is guilty of such misrepresentation of facts and hyperbolical statements to the detriment of his country, as it are contained in his writings, can only be pronounced an an'i nationalist. We are well aware that his interest in the affairs and people of Egypt is of the keenest, and on each a point we could heartily agree with him, but in making it his obvious aim to sully the Damer L of Great Britain in hør dealings with a country which she has spatched from the abyss of bankraptoy and slavery and raised almost to t the pinnsole of prosperity be estranges that lo sympatby which serions men could otherwise hold for him. There might be some slight excuse were Mr. Blunt ignorant of this country and its people, but he has passed a considerable It portion of twenty-five years in Egypt, during which time he has seriously studied the customs of the modern Egyptians, and he cannot have b failed to note the unwavering maroh of progrezat that the country has made under our guidance. 1. Indeed, one is driven to doubt the sincerity 1. of the land of Little Englanders whose cry of "British Injustice in Egypt” is now so prominent, especially in view of the fact that one of the most conspicuous of these has a full knowledge of the country from personal experience.

That Mr. Blunt's latest publication will receive credence in England is hardly likely, for, happily, the majority of the home Press have dealt with the regrettable incident of Danishwai in that equitable spirit which is still the prədominant characteristic of the Britisher, despite the attempts of a small declamatory party to persuade the world of the contrary. There is the danger, however, that it may, in conjunction with the impetuous orations of certain members of Parliament and vehement arterioles of a few journalists lead some to doubt the wisdom with which the representatives of Great Britain are directing the Government of Egypt, and, though there will speedily be convinced of the injaatios of such a consolation if they are to study the question more deeply, a certain amount of mischief may be caused. It is somewhat remarkable that Mr. Blant should play a prominent part in the endeavour of a few self-styled nationalists to foment the native to the verge of fanaticism, when he asserts such interest in their welfare, as he must surely realise that any forcible demonstration would be to the serious disadvantage of the people. The irrationality of Mr. Blunt and his fellow antinationaliste, in addition to filling us with contempt, draws upon us the contomely of foreign nations, who come to the not unnatural conclusion that the abundance of Anglophobe Britishers is an indication of the deterioration of our race. As the crow pounces with avidity upon carriou, so such men seize every opportunity to belittle their fellow countrymen in the eyes of other nations. England, alas, is being nauseated by an unparalleled wave of anti-British hysteria, which became epidemic at the commencement of the Boer war, and the sound of raucous voices pouring undeserved reproach upon men who are conscientiously and successfally striving to further the interests of countries which the first Power of the world has taken under her wing has become sufficiently common to constitute a peril to the Empire. It is deplorable that men of our own nationality endeavour to hide their utter lack of patriotism and a spurious cloak of humanitarianism, and hold up to the world as martyrs semi-barbarians who have been guilty of an extraordinarily brutal outrage. Such absolute anti-nationalism is incomprehensible, and the attempt of our Little-Englanders to drive their mother-country on to the rooks is worse than dastardly.

div.head:
THE MONEY FAMINE.
GOVERNMENT TO THE RESCUE
div.p: The prevailing scarcity of gold has today been very considerably alleviated by the prompt action of the Government in conjunction with the National Bank. Certain funds hich are not available in ordinary cases have been placed as a temporary measure by the Government at the National Bank's disposal. The mere knowledge of this fact, combined with the ansidance given by the Bank to the market, has changed the aspect of affairs, and by financial ciroles have resumed their normal activity at this season of the year.

The thanks of the financial and mercantile community are due to the Egyptian Government for the ready way it took measures to meet a situation which was causing serious inconvenience not only in Alexandria, but also in Cairo and the interior.

It appears to be popularly believed that if a State Bank was in existence in Egypt, it would be able to prevent any similar crisis owing to its large reserve. But if each bank were established, it would in all probability find it advantageous to keep its reserve in London just as the other banks do, seeing that money can be obtained by telegram in six days. To keep a large reserve permanently in Egypt would involve loss of interest during the summer to a considerable extent. As was remarked yesterday, it has been suggested that the Government and the Caisse de la Dette are somewhat to be blamed for the existing stringency, and so much money gets looked upon its receipt in payment of taxes. But it would be as well to remind our readers that, in virtue of the Anglo-French Agreement of 1904, the receipts of the land tax are paid in to the Caisse de la Dette, which has no power to release these items, while the balance of the Government revenues are sufficient at this beginning of the year to meet the outgoings in the shape of ordinary expenditure. Consequently no blame for such a stringency can fall on the Government. It is, on the contrary, the banks upon whom the responsibility falls in failing to be prepared for such an extraordinary contingency by making proper provision. On the other hand we do not consider that the banker can be held to be so fall of foresight as to anticipate such unexampled prices at the opening of the cotton season. It will be remembered that temporary crises of this patare are by no means unprecedented in the commercial records of Alexandria, and all such crises have been invariably alleviated in all few days time by the arrival of money from London.

As the currency of Egypt is practicably in British sovereigns, it is very easy to remedy any stringency by merely wiring to London. If, however, the currency were partly Egyptian, it is quite possible that a most serious situation would arise under similar circumstances.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Lady Valda Machell, the wife of the Adviser of the Ministry of the Interior, was delivered of a daughter still born, at St. James's Palace on the 25th ulto.

Mr. and Lady Valda Machell have been staying at St. James's Palace in the rooms which have been lent to them by Princess Victor Hohenlobe, who is herself at Frensham for the time being. We understand that Mr. Machell leaves London today to join the P. & 0. mail steamer Osiris at Brindisi, and is due here on Wednesday.
H.h. Aziz Pasha Izzst, under-secretary to the Ministry for Foreign affairs, arrived in Cairo on Wednesday evening on his return from Europe.
Mahmoud Pasha Sidki, Governor of Cairo, came down to Alexandria yesterday evening.

Dean Butcher has been staying at Wesson Jon Lake Walensee. We regret to hear that he has been confined to his bed for some days. A sudden abnormal drop in the temperature brought on a rather severe bronobial attack, but we are glad to learn that the attack is yielding to treatment, and we hope that he will soon recover his strength.

Professor Gottschlich, sanitary inspector of Alexandria, has returned to Egypt from Europe and resumed his official duties. He has been attending the medical congress at Lisbon on behalf of the Alexandria Municipality.
Mr. James Wilson, of Newcastle University, has been appointed professor at the school of arts and crafts at Boulac.

div.head: THE ISIS DISASTER.
MAILS ON SUNDAY.
div.p: We are informed by the bad office of the Postal Administration that the Brindisi mail will arrive at Port Said at six o'clock tomorrow evening and that the Alexandria distribution will commence at 8 a.m. on Sunday. It will be observed from the Reuter's telegram which we append that the Isis has been sufficiently repaired to be able to continue her voyage. Doubtless she will be accompanied by the Persis, which as we reported yesterday, went to her help on receipt of the bows at Port Baid, so that in the event of further break down every assistance will be at hand.

Among the passengers who, according to Reuter's despatch of the day before yesterday,ran so great a risk of serious injury; were Mr. H. Ampinall, the popular secretary to the Torf Clab, Cairo, and Mr. George Walker, of the firm of Messrs. Walker and Meimaracbi.
The weekly Brindisi mail will be made up at the G. P. O., Alexandria, on Sunday at 3.10 p.m. for ordinary correspondence. Registered letters must be posted one hour earlier.
The Isis has left with passengers and mails for Port Ssid, where she is expected to arrive on Saturday. (Reuter)

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to perrott-within a certain necessary limit free discussion.
OFFICIALS AND CIVILIANS.

div.head: To The EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."
div.p: Sir,---It is a thousand pities that "A Mere Business Man" should have so mis-read the letter I wrote to you from the Fayoum a few days ago. I was then labouring under the impression that I was accusing one of your correspondents of snobbishness in speaking slightingly of the benefits of a Board School Education. I ventured to point out the superiority of a Board School Education to that of Public School and 'Varsity, and I spok, of the latter form of education as being possibly a misfortune. Will "A eore Business Man" do me the favoar of reading my letter once again and more carefully, and then informing me whence he infers that I consider that the British Commercial Community here has enjoyed a Board School education! No such insinuation was made, and moreover the benefits of a Board School Education were described as superior to those of a 'Varsity and Publio Bohool education. How the remarks in my letter could have been so distorted as to bring about a meaning contrary to that intended is hard to imagine. There seems to be considerable bitterness shown on the part of the unofficial correspondents in this controversy. Let them rest assured that this bitterness is in no way reciprocated, and that the greatest admiration, and respect for our commercial fellow countrymen here, who do so much to keep England’s name and reputation bright, are felt by all Anglo-Egyptian officials, not excluding

div.head: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE ."
div.p: Sir,---The charge made against "five or six civilian officials” by your correspondent "Ex. Officio" appears to me to be an argument in favor of my original suggestion, that all Government officials or employés should wear the tarbush as a protection against being taken for members of the commercial community. Surely if the official clsdd adopted the suggestion made in my letter of the 19th September and, wore some distinguishing badge no such charge as that referred to above could be made against a community composed of gentlemen who are mostly University scholars, and who as such, I feel sure, would never disgrace themselves in the manner stated to have occurred in the small hours of the morning.--I am, etc.
div.byline: ANOTHER RESIDENT OF OVER 80 YEARS'S STANDING.

div.head: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."
div.p: Sir. — The ideal condition of existence in Cairo would be a community of Anglo-Egyptian officials, undisturbed by the presence of any commercial people of their own race. The British commercial man is doubtless a very well-meaning person in his way, but his presence introduces a certain jarring note and I fully sympathise with the attitude of French and German officialdom, who in the so-called colonies of those nations do their best to ensure a tranquil life by suppressing the commercial men of their own race by making their existence intolerable. However, for good or ill, such is not the policy of the British Government and at Cairo we should learn to tolerate them. We need not arouse their irritation by us patronising airs and should always rather adopt a condescending attitude to this class of human beings, but at the same time if they consider that their racial relationship to us affords them a special right to criticise, they should be taught to keep to their place. The best way of treating these people is to adopt an attitude of studied irony towards them. Sach treatment would prevent them from becoming familiar, as it appears to puzzle them.---I am, truly yours.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.)

En raison de la pénurie monétaire qui sévit sur notre marché, ou est étonné de ne constater ioi qo'one baisse partielle et d'aillenrs insignifiante. Ce résultat inattenda proviendrait da découvert qui cherche à profiter des bas prix aotaols pour se racheter. Si telle est la vérité, il n'y régasit que médiocrement, car les transactions demeurent à peu près pulles.

La Ramleh Railway, la Bière da Caire, la Salt and Soda, la Cassa di Soonto, les Nangovich Hotele, le Trust, le Comptoir pouvelle émission et les Building Landa sont apjourd'hui vendonra au prix auquel ils étaient hier achetours.

D'autre part, la National Bank est demandée à 26 1/2, les Markets s'avancent à 25/9, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier à 336 1/2, le: Lots Tarog à 147 1/2, la Lald Bank à 8 31/32, les Estates sont demandés à 1 13,16 et l'Union Foncière est très ferme à 6 livres, acheteurs.

Comme il pourrait y avoir retard ou insuffi sance dans les arrivages d'or d'Earope, il est possible que la reprise se fase e attendre encore quelques jours, mais la fermeté relative qui prédomine actuellement sur notre marché n'en est pag moins d'excellent angare pour i'avenir.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny

div.p: Le Caire, 4 Octobre.

Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres se maintient à 4 1/2 pour cont. Hier, an Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a clôturé encore invarié à 86 5/8, de même que l'Unifiée à 104 1/4, la National Bank å 26 7/8, l'Agricole à 9 3/4 et la Daïra à 16 3/4. Seule la D:lta Light est renseignée en avance de 1/8 à 11 3/4.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a perda. 3 francs à 780. La Banqae d'Athènes : Bat restée stationnaire à 146.

Les perspectives d'ane aggravation passagère de la tension monétaire de Londres et aussi d'an resserrement local ont visiblement pour effet de restreindre les transactions. Il s'engait qae les cours se tassent, sans pourtant déter. miner une orientation réelle à la baisse. Lei plas pessimistes semblent ne pas perdre de vue que les prix sont bas, qui nous entrons dans la période de reprise des affaires, que les appréhensions au sojet d'un plas grand renchérissement da loyer de l'argent sont pent être exagéréer, et que, d'aillears, de noavelles dépressions auraient poar résultat forcé de! provoquer des achats et d'amgner soudaine. ment ane reprise.
Aussi bien, notre marché des valeurs reste dans l'expectative, et les cours pratiqué; ce matin sont en moins-value légère sur toute la oote, à peu d'exceptions près.
Le compartiment des Banques a été généra. lemant faible. La National Bank a débuté à 26 11/16 pour terminer à 26 9/16. L'Agricole
Aéchi à 9 5/8-11/16. La Cassa di Sconto a! opoora réactionné å 226 l'action ancienne; la nouvelle est restée à 220.
L'action Crédit Fonciar a été ramenée à 776. 777; l'obligation à lots ancienne est revenne à 336. L. Daïra est descendae à 16 3/4-13/16.
L. Béhéra a avanoé de 1/8 a 36 1/2 La Nile Land a rétrogradé à 15 5/8.
L'action Enterprise and Davelopment a perda 8/16 à 12 9/16 et la part de fondateur 3/3 à 91 5/8.
Les Improvements ont fléobi à 5 9/16 pour olótarer plas fermes à 5 9/16-5/8. L'Agricole du Nil a molli à 264-265.
L'action Allotment a baissé à 3 1/4-5/16 ; par contre, la part de fondateur est remontée à 123.
En très bonna tendance, l'action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaax s'est raffermie à 4. 5/16; la part de fondateur a débuté à 78 pour olótarer 80.
Les Ciments ont perda 2 frano: à 68. Les dividende: Tramways d'Alexandrie ont décliné, à 835. L'action Antomobiles da Cuire a pro. grossé à 6-6 1/16 et la part de fondateur à 10 1/2.

Dans le groupe des valeurs bôtelières, los Nangovich ont été délaissés à 17 5/16-3/8 Les Egyptian se sont msintenus à 6 5/16-3/8. L38 Upper Egyyt ont réctionné à 5. L. part de fondatear National Hotel est revenue à 58.

Les Estates ont été traités pendant presque toute la séanog à 1 27/32 pour finir à 1 13/16, ache. teurs ; la part de fondateur a baissé jas qu'à 11 3/8 poar o'Q'orer ferme à 11 5/8-11/16. Les Hooker ont été offerts à 0 15/16 1 et les Salt and Soda à 21 eh. Les Glymenopoulo ont faibli à 1 3/8 et les Abdy à 1 3/16-1/4. Les New Egyptian sont remontés à 30 sh.
L’Egyptian la.provements Corporation vient de vendre une partie des terrains qu'elle poe. sédait au bord de Nil, à Ghezireh, aveo an hénéfice net représenten: 125 % du prix qa'elle avait payé.
Oa rapporte que la Société refuso actaelle. mont de céder le solde de ces terreius & up prix laissant 135 % de profit.

D'aat part, le domaine de 12,000 mètres carrés. sitné derrière la propriété Gianaclia, que l'Improvements Corporation a acquis tout récemment, sorait, dit on, sur le point d'être acheté par un groupe à un prix et à des conditiona de paiement qui feraient ressortir encore mieax 164 avantages que la Socié:e retirera de cette affair

div.head: AUFGEBOT.
div.p: Es wird zur allgemeinen Kenntnis gebracht, dass

1) der Königliche Amtsrichter Hugo Gott fried Benno vod Valtier wohnhaft in Thorn Westpreisbon Gerechtestrasse 30. Sohn des Freischalzerei-Besitz yrs Benno von Vaitier und seiner Ehefrau Bertha geborenen Karpoweks, ersterer verstorben, zaletzt wohnhaft in Grau. denz le'ztere wohnhaft in Thorn ;

2) die onverehalichte, von Beruf Lebrerin, Frida Elsbeth Hempel, wohnhaft in Bromberg Provinz Poson, Wilhelmstrasse 51, früber in Alexandrien, Tochter des Rittergutabe i zers August Hempel und seiner Ebefrau Louise geborenen H-yer, ersterer wohnhaft in Brom. berg, letztere verstorben, zaletzt wobnbafo in (onbekannt) die Ehe mit einander eingehen wollen.
Die Bekanntmachung des Aufgebots bat in den Sälten Thorn, Bromberg and Alex. andrien za geschehen.
Thorr, den 28. September 1906.
Dor Standesheamte.
In Vertretung.
(L. S.)GEZ. HERTELL.

div.head: SOCIETE GENERALE DES Surceries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte
div.p: Siege SOCIAL AU CAIRE

Par décision de l'Assemblée Générale extraordinaire des Actionnairəs, tenue au Caire le 24 Mars 1906, le Capital nominal de 32,500,000 francs, divisé en 325,000 Actions ordinaires de 100 francs, doit être, par rédaction des deux tiers, ramené à 10,833,400 frang, divisé en 108,334 Actions ordinaires. Une Action nonvelle doit être remisé en échange de trois anciennes.

Bo ontre, aux termes de concordat voté par l'Assemblée des c:éanoiers, le 23 Mai 1906, et homologué par jogement da Trib inal mixte da Caire, le 2 Juio suivant, les 102,405 obligations ordicaires de 500 francs 4 % restant en cinulation doivent être échangées contre de nouvelles obligations ordinaires de 400 Fce. romboarsables à 500 francs en 60 ans, à ravena variable, maximun 5% avec échéance da 1° Juillet 1909 pour le premier coopon.

Au moment de l'échange des obligations, les poeteurs pourront demander l'échange por et simple ou l'échange avec l'estampille donnant droit à un coupon annuel de 8 francs, pendant 3 ans, payable par semestre, pour le premier paiement qoi doit avoir lieu le 1° Juillet 1906, et ce aux charges et conditions de l'article 3 da oncordat. L'option pour l'estampille des Titres prend fin le 31 Décembre 1906. Les porteurs des Titres (Actions et Obligations) pourront les déposer, à partir de ce jour, contre un reça provisoire à échanger ultérien. rement contre les nouveaux Titres.

L'Administration des Chemins de Fer de 'Etat a l'honneur d'informer le Pablio que la Station de "Moalla” située entre Chagab er Matasna (Ligne Louxor-Assouan) sera à partir da 11 Octobre 1906, ouverte pour le service des voyageurs et transport des bagages et apimanı en Grande Vitesse aux prix et condi. tions da Tarif des Voyagear: en vigueur.
Toatefois des billets directs et l'enregistremant direct des bagages et animaux de ou poar El-Moalls ne se ferait que de et pour les gares de la voie étroite (Louxor-Chellal).

Pour les voyages et transports des gares de la voie normale (au-delà de Louxor) & deatination d'El-Moalla et réci,rcquement, les billets et récépissés seront émis pour Louxor senlement, d'où l'on devra prendre de non vasax billets et effecteur un noavel eoregistrement par les soins et aux frais des voyageurs on des expéditeurs.

President Roosevelt, speaking at Harrisburg, said that a narrow interpretation of the powers of the Government was the chief bulwark of those great monied interests which oppose the attempt to place them under efficient government control. The forces of freed must be checked so as to eponre justice being done with regard to labour and capital. It behoves Americans to seek the right kind of civilisation, which shall not be more platocracy as represented by the Banking house or Wall! Street syndicate.
(Reuter)
164 persons have been killed and 596 wounded in the streets of the city during the last four months.
(Reuter)
The police have seized 110 bombs and quantity of dynamite at the Engineering School of the Ministry of Railways here.

The lawlessness existing in the capital is farther evidenced by the daring attempt of a band of men to waylay a Government messenger carrying large some of money, near the Bourse. The police were forewarned and watchad the messenger. A regular pitched battle ensued, and the assailants were driven off. (R.)
The Tzar has returned to Peterhof.
Havas.
An Imperial decree has been issued anthorising the sale of 20,000,000 acres of Siberian land to peasants.
(Reuter)
The Miners' Federation, met at Swansea, decided against joining the Keir Hardie party.
(Reuter)

In spite of the triumph of the Labourites at Cardiff, Mr. Bell insists that the resolutions do not represent the views of a large bulk of railway servants. He demands that a general ballot should be taken.
(Reuter)

The emigrant ship Charterhouse foundered near here. The captain and 60 passengers were drowned. The chief engineer and 23 of tbe. orow and two women were picked up, after having being 43 hours on a raft.
(Reuter)
The S. S. Charterhouse has foundered off Cape Hainan. Sixty emigrants are missing.
(Havas)
The Lord Mayor and Sheriffs will take the State coaches with them on the occasion of their visit to Paris, on the 14th instant.
The Théatre has been destroyed by fire.

div.head: THE SOLDIER'S FUTURE.
div.p: THE RESERVIST'S LIVELIHOOD.
The article which we, in part, reproduced from our contemporary the "Tribune" yesterday under the heaving of the Soldier's Future" continues follows:----

What is the existing machinery for setting down the Reservist to a means of livelihood. In London there are certain societies, some State aided in small degree, but all (with one exception) largely dependent on voluntary gopport, who are busily engaged in the work. The Committee elicited from the representatives of each the methods by which the end is rough and the rules governing its activity. The result was the discovery of a considerable amount of overlapping, almost inevitable in the circumstances. We will mention the chief organisations.

The Army and Navy Pensioners and TimeExpired Men's Employment Society, established in 1855, endeavours to procure situations for pensioners and time-expired men of "good" character. No pecuniary assistance is given to the med, nor are spy fees charged. Towards its funds the War Office makes a grant of £100, regiments and private individuals subscribe, and there is the interest on a small investment. The society found employment, either temporary or permanent, for 2,832 men in 1902 3, for 2,520 in 1903-4, and for 2,390 in 1904 5. According to the evidence of Colonel C. R. Shervinton, its definition of temporary employment is daily pay, at an average of 48., and of permanent, a work to-week engagement, at about 258.

The National Association for the Employment of Reserve and Discharged Soldiers, whose work was described by Mr. Haldane at its last annual meeting as being "as much & part of the organisation of the Army as the War Office itself," has existed since 1886, and covers a wide area. It has 114 branches, of which 27 are supported by local subscriptions supplemented by grants from the central association, while the remaining 87 are managed from the headquarters of the regimental distriots and the offices of the Recruiting Staff Officers in the large towns. A Government grant of £1,000 is supplemented by the in.l. terest on an investment of £2,000 and by inscriptions from canton and regimental fords and from private sources. It endeavours to soonre permanent employment for ex-soldiers (including Royal Marines) of "good” character, registering, as a role, only the names of those who have left or been discharged from the Army within a period of three months preceding the date of their application for employment. This tightening top of the conditions is A recent innovation necessitated by the large number of applicants remaining on the books. of the association. In 1902-3 permanent em-11 ployment-namely, anything over a three months' engagement—was found for 13,909, in 1903 4 for 11,068, in 1904-5 for 8,603, and 1905 6 for 8,684. Temporary employment was also found for 2,100 men in 1904 5, and for 2,726 in 1905-6, but a record of the class of employment in previous years was not kept

Unlike the two foregoing organizations, the Incorporated Soldiers' and Sailors' Help Society is chiefly charitable in its operations, and hardly comes within the boope of this review, excepting in so far as it aims at providing its clients with the name and address of a "friend" in each parish throughout the Empire who endeavours to provide employ. møpt or other help, and in teaching needle trades to men discharged 88 medically unfit and who are unable to obtain ordinary employment. It receives a grant of £50 from Army funds, and is otherwise supported by regiments, ships, and private persons, and in 1902 found employment for 4,900 men, in 1903 for 5,493, in 1904 for 5,593 and in 1905 for 4,704. It places on its register all men, except those of "bad" character.

Perhaps the best known, because the most evident, of all these beneficent agencies is the Corps of Commissionaires, whose 3,046 members are a public part of daily life. The report succinctly observes: It is quite an unique organization, its members are under discipline, and are governed by a special code of rules, covering sick, savings bank, ipsorance, and pension funds, and the principles on which it is worked are that the men most support them elves." As Colonel M. Mo Neill Rind expressed it : "the whole principle of the corps is 'No outside financial assistance'; the commissioner must entirely support himself," and this is done, with the result that the ranks are always filled with the most trustworthy of servants. Then come the purely regimental organisations, mainly supported by past and present officers, such as the Brigade of Guards Employment Society, which has placed 647 in the last four years ; the Irish Guarda, which bag a special arrangement by which a certain number of its men may be enlisted in the Royal Irish Constabulary, the Royal Engineer's Labour Bureau and the Rifleman's Aid E Society, both of which keep registers and I work in co-operation with the other employment agencies.

There are certain other associations, described in the report as "miscellaneous,” which are working in the gare direction, and a reference to them completes the list of yolaptary agencies--the only method at present in existence - through whose instrumentality the Reservist or time expired soldier oan come into immediate touch with the civilian employer. In the place of these moltifa:ions and over. lapping organizations the Committee recom| mends the establishment of one central body financially assisted by, not under the control of, the Admiralty and War Office, with affiliated branches in counties and towns.

div.head: MARVELS OF SURGERY
TRANSPLANTATION OF VEINS
div.p: At a recent meeting of the Congress of Natural Research and Medicine at Stuttgart, Professor Garre, of Breslau, delivered an interesting lecture on the transplanting of blood Vessels and organs, the topio which attracted to much attention at the meeting of the British Medical Association at Toronto in August, where instances were given of the transplantation of kidneys from one dog to another.

Professor Garre mentioned a recent case in which a child of four years' suffering from eretinjam had a portion of its mother's thyroid gland transplanted into its spleen. After nine months the child was beginning to develop intellectually, and to walk and talk.

He had, he said, succeeded in removing blood-vessels " six centimetres (2 inches) long, not only from live animale, but from animals which had been dead an hour and a half, to other animals. While it was not. possible to remove and transplant large blood vessels from living human beings, yet blood vessels could be suitably taken from freshly amputated limbs. Such transplanting would be of great age in many cases in modern surgery, for instance when, in removing large tumors, large blood-vessels have to be tied up, which often results fatally for the parts of the body fed by these blood vessels.

Professor Garre described experiments which he had made in transplanting kidneys. He had removed the kidney of a dog and sewed it in the same animal's deck so that the nephritio artery was joined to the carotid artery, and the nephritic veins to the veins of the neck.
He had farther sewed the kidney of a dog in the body of another dog with such success that the transplanted kidney had performed its natural fapotions perfectly.

div.head: MARK TWAIN'S AUTOBIOGRAPHY.
div.p: "INTRODUCING” HIS ANCESTORS.

The autobiography of Mark Twain, which is being published in Serial form by an American journal, contains a good "story" about the late Mr. William Walter Phelps, when the latter was United States Minister, at the Court of Berlin.

"One evening he had me to dipnor to meet Count 8., a Cabinet Minister," writes Mark Twain. "This nobleman was of long and illustrious descent. Of course, I wanted to let oot the fact that I had some ancestors, too ; but I did not want to pull them out of their graves by the ears, and I never could seem to get the chance to work them in in a way that would look sufficiently casual. I suppose Phelps was in the same difficulty. In fact, he looked distraught, now and then-just as a person looks who wants to uncover an ancestor purely by accident and cannot think of a way that will seem accidental enough. But at last, after the dipper, he made & try. He took us about his drawing-room, showing us the pictures, and finally stopped before & rade and ancient engraving. It was a picture of the court that tried Charles I. There was a pyramid of judges in Paritan blouch hats, and below them three bareheaded secretaries seated at a table. Mr. Phelps put his finger opon one of the three and said with exalting indifference :
" 'An ancestor of mine.'
"I pat my finger on a jadge and retorted with soathing languidno88 :
"'Ancestor of mine. But it is a small matter. I have others.'
"It was not noble in ma to do it. I have always regretted it since. But it landed him."

div.head: THE KRUGER FORTUNE
div.p: Since the late Boor war a new phase of treasure hunting has been in vogue, writes Douglas Blackburn, in "Chambers's Journal.".

Someone started a rumour that ere his de. partare from the Transvaal the late President had a quantity of bar-gold, variously estimated at a value ranging from one to several mil. lions, conveyed ap-country and buried. The story received so much credevoe that the British Government at Pretoria has provided special permits and police assistance to various persons who professed to be able to guide a search-party to the hiding place.

The degree of gullibility that even intelligent and educated men can attain when ex. cited by treasure mania was amusingly illustrated by a well-known instance. A young Boer from the district supposed to contain the treasure called upon a doctor near Johannesburg, and told a strange story. He said that one night while riding to the farm of a relative he saw lights in a wooded kloof or gorgé, and reconnoitring cautiously, he saw a party of men removing boxes from a wagon and burying them. Carefully noting the spot, he got away unobserved, and returned next day, when he unearthed a box, which, on being broken open, he found to contain bars of gold and quantities of Kroger sovereigns minted on one side only. In confirmation of the story he produced three discs of gold which appeared to have been struck on one side with an imperfect die. His object in calling on the doctor was to borrow fifty pounds in order to procuré a Waggon and oxen to remove the treasure. He was asked why he did not bring away the portable coins and thus make himself independent of outside financial aid. His explanation was ingenuous. He feared to bring more lest he might be found with them upon him!
It is estimated that over ten thousand pounds have been expended by the various search-parties that have undertaken the search for the Kruger millions.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB.
div.p: To-morrow, let us remind our readers, is the day fixed for the fourth annual aquatic sports of the Alexandria Swimming Club, which will be held in the new Gabbari graving dock, commencing at a quarter to three. Extra interest is attached to the programme by the addition of a race of 860 yardo between the teams of the Alexandria Rowing Club, the Club Nautique Français, the Club Internazionale Canottieri, and the Deutscher Sportverein, which should be one of the best contested events of the programme. We are glad to learn that the sale of tickets has far exceeded that of former years, so that these sports may be expected to eclipse their forerunners in every BOD88. The following is the programme :
60 Yards Junior Handicap;
60 Yards Veteran Handicap ;
Final 60 Yards Members Handicap;
Junior Diving Championship;
Plunging Championship;
Polo Match;
360 Yards Invitation Team Race ;
Three Widths Blindfold Race";
Diving Championship;
Obstacle Race;
Military Polo Match ;
Walking the Pole ;
Military Tug of War,

A special prize will be presented by the Club to the member producing the six best photographic snapshots of the sports. Mr. M. Hackmayer's orchestra will play a beleotion of music during the afternoon.

Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;

2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette. "
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."
